and just needs to go into my account?

paid?

Thanks,
Paul

Dear Mr Taylor

I hope you are well and settling into your new home.

The mortgage broker fee query was raised the day of legal completion, following the completion statement being agreed.

It was communicated via our solicitors and before completion this fee did not form part of our agreement, therefore any cost associated to this, was not the responsibility of Crest Nicholson.


Kind regards

Subject: Re: Urgent: Re: appointment on Wednesday
From: Richard Kirby <r.kirby@trinity-rose.co.uk>
To: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>, Jade Taylor
 <jade.millington@hotmail.co.uk>
Date: Mon, 9 Oct 2023 15:03:26 +0000
Further to our earlier exchange of emails, I have just had a call from a Donna Hack of Crest Nicholson asking if we were attending on Wednesday.  I advised her of your message this morning - that you had been informed that Crest had decided not to pay our fees.

She has clarified Crest's position - that they will pay the 2,500 for Wednesday's inspection, but that it will be down to you to pay the 1,500 fee for work in relation to 25 Abbots Road.

I advised I wasn't happy with that, as we will be left 1500 out of pocket.  She then consulted her director but I have not been given any further clarity on the position regarding that element of our fee.

Therefore, I am bringing this to your attention as, if this does not accord with your understanding of the situation, you may wish to contact her - donna.hack@crestnicholson.com.

As it stands we will attend on Wednesday, but I would like the other aspect of the fees accrued to be sorted out with Crest, as they relate to your position with 25 Abbots Road and therefore, Crest should be covering all your expenses in supporting you to get to your resolution on that property.

Kind regards, Richard




________________________________
From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
Sent: 09 October 2023 08:30
To: Richard Kirby <r.kirby@trinity-rose.co.uk>
Subject: Urgent: Re: appointment on Wednesday

Good morning Richard,

Please could you confirm whether Crest has contacted you since our last email? They are claiming that they have instructed you.

The agreement with Crest was that you were to go in once the property is build complete. I have raised several times that there is boxing which is visibly out of square. In my opinion, until that is rectified, the house can not be considered build complete, ready to be moved into.

Crest agreed to pay your fee, as per the section of email sent to you. They are now going back on that, and not willing to do so.

We were not aware that that time was going

Subject: Fwd: FW: Mr and Mrs Taylor  - 25 Abbots Road/34 Albany Wood - subject
 to contract
From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
To: Jade Taylor <jade.millington@hotmail.co.uk>
Date: Fri, 13 Oct 2023 12:46:28 +0100
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
Date: Fri, 13 Oct 2023 at 12:45
Subject: Re: FW: Mr and Mrs Taylor - 25 Abbots Road/34 Albany Wood -
subject to contract
To: Hannah Rafferty <hr@bramsdonandchilds.com>, Serhan Handani <
sh@bramsdonandchilds.com>


Good Morning Hannah/Serhan,

The memorandum that their solicitors have kindly forwarded to you states in
section 2.2.2 that, in addition to the price (2):

*2.2.2: "The reasonable and proper legal fees that they incur with respect
to the purchase of a new home to which their family moves."*

For them to be given a response, we would need Serhan to act on our behalf,
a service which should then still be covered under the Memorandum of Sale.
If Serhan's time is not covered for this, then the solicitor dealing with
the Memorandum of Sale and Reservation Agreement should not be contacting
you, and perhaps needs to be made aware of this as they wouldn't receive a
response, which I'm sure they are expecting, as would Crest. They require
the mortgage redemption statement and proof of non-portability, therefore
need to pay for Serhan's time.

I have a transcript of a call with Adrian Sims, the Managing Director, from
several months ago when this entire situation was first being discussed,
who assured us that we would need to be happy with the home before
completion. If this is not going to be the case, this needs to be recorded
as a discrepancy and is quite serious for someone at his level to state
this in a conversation then do the exact opposite (I am aware that
conversations recorded for personal use can be shared with legal
representatives but no one else, and I can confirm that they have not been):

My first thing is that, obviously we made an offer as a buyback for your
> home. That would be a full and final settlement of everything, [....] So I
> would definitely want to keep these things separate. You can then go and
> use your money

when this will be completed. I assume the farmer will be liaised with to
have the railings removed which prevented further access to Crest, after
the previous attempt to block it was removed by Crests' groundworkers.
Path Issue

path linking both developments, which you have stated Crest wi

to be, a full survey.

This was never agreed:

> 1.16.1 Any defects not identified by the third party surveyor;
>

If I see something that is not within NHBC tolerances or standards, that is
still a breach of standards, no matter who discovered it.

I don't see any mention of the 3 days permission to occupy that was
confirmed by Natalie Haigh. Please could you let me know if I've just
missed this?

Do you have any contacts with the local council to confirm whether they are
going to reject the offer of the open land?  If they don't want Crest in
the town anymore, they really need to take it on so they don't try to get
planning permission on it.

There's a lot to go through, but even though it's my birthday I'll try to
get it read this evening.

Many thanks,
Paul

wanted to exchange and complete as soon as possible, which has no relevance

legal contract.

surveyor but can't prove it, since the final certification was never given.

understand why they feel they can pick and choose what they will abide by
and what they will not.

They are also, despite it being listed in the reservation agreement,
refusing to put a second instance of incorrect DPC right, claiming that the
NHBC standards are only guidelines.  A guideline does not state a minimum
measurement for tolerances.  DPC tolerances are a part of the NHBC's
technical standards.

Dear Mrs Taylor,



Thank you for your email. I shall consider it in detail when I can.



Crest have not agreed to cover all my costs. I am concerned that my costs will be significant as you are effectively asking me to bring your claims formally (albeit not in court) rather than simply advise on the agreement reached.



I can see that they have agreed to cover the costs in reviewing and agreeing the memorandum only. They are not agreeing to cover legal costs in further negotiation or litigation.



At this stage I would estimate my costs to negotiate this further will be in the region of £1,500 to £2,000 plus VAT but may be significantly more depending on how the case proceeds.



My preliminary view, which I believe I have shared with you by telephone, is that further compensation will be very difficult to justify in law. As far as I could tell, Crest’s offer ensures that you have not financially lost any sums.



It seems clear that Crest are not willing to pay more than they have already offered.



I cannot see legal justification for your previous expenses on your property (such as mortgage payments and utilities) to be covered. These are expenses you would have borne irrespective of Crest’s actions and are almost certainly unclaimable.



I am out of the office this afternoon so I am afraid I cannot call you.



Kind regards,



Serhan Handani, LL.B (Hons), LL.M

Paul
